div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to George Miller Sternberg, June 17, 1899
div1.opener:
Agramonte still giving no evidence of
interest in the mosquito theory
Yellow-Fever Hospital
Havana, June 17th 1899.
To Brig. Gen. Geo. M. Sternberg,
Surgeon General U.S.A.
Washington D.C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
Yours of the 5th inst. enclosing check
for $100 - has duly come to hand, for the
purchase of animals or other incidental
expenses in connection with my work here.
I shall render you account with its proper
vouchers, from time to time.

There has been but one case of yellow-
fever at this hospital which could furnish
me with material for investigation; although
several others have been admitted on suspicion,
they turned out to be alcoholics, malarial,
one case of septic infection, catarrhal jaundice,
typhoid fever etc. Two other cases that have
been recorded as yellow fever are so
observe and subject to dispute that I
do not feel warranted in including them
with the typical cases which it is my
duty to investigate.

One of these two cases was a boy, 10 yrs old,
Cuban, sick in all 3 days. Vomitted once
or twice, did not become icteric, small
quantity of albumen in urine is reported,
(I found none upon two examinations,)
fever left him on the 3rd day and he rapid-
ly convalesced. His blood did not “clump”
either, typhoid, coli com. b. icteroides or X.

The other case was an American young
man, prisoner at the City jail; had been
“sick” several days before admission to hospital;
had no fever when admitted or at any time
afterwards nor any symptom of yellow f.
except a yellowish tint of the conjunctivae; a
slight albuminuria is reported, but like in
the previous case I failed to corroborate its
presence.

The case that did have yellow fever cannot
be disputed. I made cultures from his
blood upon several occasions during his
illness; those planted directly from the
vein, remained sterile; others from
blood of the ear-lobe were sometime con-
taminated. Bac. icteroides has not oc-
curred at any time.

His blood agglutinated bac. icteroides and
bac. coli com. at various times; at others, it
failed to do so.

After the convalescence was well advanced
I decided to try the action of his blood-serum
upon animals inoculated with b. icteroides.
To be concise, I copy from my notes.

June 4th 1899. Venesection upon Pascual Rodriguez,
convalescing from yellow fever, in the 5th week
after infection. General condition good though
still markedly icteric and somewhat anoemic.
Drew 184 c.c. of blood from bend of the elbow.
Obtained therefrom 32 c.c. of clear serum after return.
This serum has a slow “clumping” power upon
bac. icteroides; in a proportion of 1:10 after 20 min.
no action in proportion of 1:20, after 1 hour.

June 5th G. Pig no. 12 right 320 grm. Subcutaneous
injection 0.3 c.c. of a 24 hr. bouil. cult. b. icteroides
(control pig.) Died after 28 hours. B. icteroides
recovered from the viscera and blood.

G. Pig no 13. Weight 300 grm. Subcut. injection of
0.3 c.c. of 24 hr. bouil. cult. used on no 12,
also 2 c.c. of serum from Pascual Rodriguez.
Died June 7th (48 hrs). B. icteroides recovered.

G. Pig no14. Light 325 grm. Subent. injection
0.4 c.c. of culture used upon no 12 and 13.
also 2.5 c.c. of serum from Pascual Rodriguez.
Died June 9th (3 days, 8 hrs.) Bac. icteroides recovered.
June 9th Dog no 15. Light 8 1/2 lbs. Intravenous in-
jection of 24 hr. bouil cult. b. icteroides, (5 c.c.
injected) having previously injected 15 c.c.
of serum from Pascual Rodriguez. The dog
was very sick for 5 days and then died.
The organism was recovered from the viscera.

The above experiments, which I purpose to repeat
as opportunity presents itself, hardly tend to show

the existence of any etiological relation between
bac. icteroides and yellow fever.

A small quantity of blood was obtained from
a case of yellow f. at the private sanatorium
“Quinta del Rey;” I was not permitted to puncture
a vein and had therefore to be content with blood
from the ear lobe. I can report no definite
results as yet.

At Dr. Carroll's request I have sent him
some capillary tubes with blood for testing
its clumping power. Shall also send sections
of viscera.

On the 15th inst. a marine soldier died at a
hospital located on the shore of the bay, sup-
posedly of yellow fever. I was not notified
of the autopsy but the surgeon in charge
(Naval) kindly sent me a piece of the
liver, from which I have made several
cultures and sections of which I send
today to Dr. Reed.

The express Co. here refuses to take any but
prepaid packages to Washington. Can any provision
be made to put my packages on Military Invoices?
This is the suggestion of the Express Co's representation.
